intro: Bifrenaria tetragona, commonly known as the four-angled balsam, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the Andes mountains. It belongs to the family Gesneriaceae and is characterized by its opposite, quadrangular stems and lanceolate leaves. The plant produces showy, bilaterally symmetrical flowers in shades of red, orange, and yellow, typically during the warmer months. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often cultivated for its ornamental value. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in the wild.
